verses.text: Now a certain woman, the wife of one of the sons of the prophets, cried out to Elisha, saying, "Your servant my husband is dead, and you know that your servant feared the LORD; but now the creditor has come to take my two children to be his slaves."
verses.comment: The widow’s situation shows the vulnerability of prophet families and the social justice provisions of the law. The fear of the Lord hints at the connection between faithful living and divine intervention.

verses.text: Elisha said to her, "What shall I do for you? Tell me, what do you have in your house?" She said, "Your servant has nothing in the house except a jar of oil."
verses.comment: The motif of the little left in the house that God uses echoes other stories of miraculous provision, prefiguring Christ’s multiplication of resources (Mark 6:38-44).

verses.text: Then he said, "Go, borrow vessels from everywhere, from all your neighbors—empty vessels; do not gather just a few."
verses.comment: The command not to gather just a few suggests a generous expectation. God’s provision is abundant for those with faith.

verses.text: "And when you have come in, you shall shut the door behind you and your sons; then pour the oil into all those vessels, and set aside each one that is full."
verses.comment: The act of closing the door emphasizes intimacy and privacy in experiencing God’s miracles—foreshadowing personal prayer with faith.

verses.text: So she went from him and shut the door behind her and her sons, who brought the vessels to her, and she poured out.
verses.comment: Obedience to the prophet is shown, highlighting the importance of cooperating with God’s messengers.

verses.text: Now when the vessels were full, she said to her son, "Bring me another vessel." He said to her, "There is not another vessel." So the oil stopped flowing.
verses.comment: The oil ceases only when there is no more capacity, symbolizing that God’s grace matches our faith’s readiness.

verses.text: Then she came and told the man of God. He said, "Go, sell the oil and pay your debt; and you and your sons can live on the rest."
verses.comment: Miracle results in both the cancellation of debt and lasting provision—a picture of both justice and mercy, and a foreshadowing of redemption.

verses.text: Now it happened one day that Elisha went to Shunem, where there was a prominent woman, and she urged him to eat some food. So whenever he passed by, he would turn in there to eat.
verses.comment: Hospitality to prophets is a consistent theme, showing the importance of recognizing and supporting God’s representatives.

verses.text: She said to her husband, "Look now, I know that this is a holy man of God who passes by us regularly."
verses.comment: Recognition of holiness in others is spiritually significant, as those close to God often impart blessings.

verses.text: "Let us make a small upper room on the wall, and put a bed, a table, a chair, and a lamp for him; so whenever he comes to us, he can turn in there."
verses.comment: The provision of a dedicated space for the prophet foreshadows the special honor for those set apart for God’s work, relating to themes of sacred dwelling.

verses.text: And it happened one day that he came there, and he turned into the upper room and lay down there.
verses.comment: Rest in the upper room has echoes in later biblical accounts, especially in gospel stories of significant meetings in upper rooms.

verses.text: Then he said to Gehazi his servant, "Call this Shunammite woman." When he had called her, she stood before him.
verses.comment: Intermediaries in miracles recall God working through chosen vessels and assistants.

verses.text: He said to him, "Say now to her, 'You have been very concerned for us with all this care. What can be done for you? Can we speak to the king or to the commander of the army for you?'" She answered, "I dwell among my own people."
verses.comment: Her humility and contentment are notable; she receives reward for faith, not ambition.

verses.text: So he said, "What then is to be done for her?" Gehazi answered, "Actually, she has no son, and her husband is old."
verses.comment: The lack of a child and her husband’s old age set up a scenario for miraculous birth, mirroring God’s action for Sarah and Elizabeth (Genesis 18:9-15; Luke 1:7), a recurring template for divine intervention.

verses.text: He said, "Call her." When he had called her, she stood in the doorway.
verses.comment: The setting of the doorway highlights transition—physical and spiritual—anticipating transformation in her life.

verses.text: Then he said, "About this time next year, you shall embrace a son." She said, "No, my lord, man of God, do not lie to your maidservant!"
verses.comment: Miraculous prophecy of birth, with disbelief, echoes Abraham and Sarah, and Zechariah and Elizabeth. Prefigures later miraculous births connected to God’s plan.

verses.text: But the woman conceived, and bore a son at the appointed time the next year, as Elisha had told her.
verses.comment: God’s word is fulfilled as promised, reinforcing His faithfulness and the role of prophetic mediation.

verses.text: The child grew, and one day he went out to his father, to the reapers.
verses.comment: The boy joins his father at work, an ordinary scene preceding a crisis—a common biblical narrative device.

verses.text: He said to his father, "My head, my head!" His father said to a servant, "Carry him to his mother."
verses.comment: The sudden illness brings urgency, underlining human helplessness and the need for God’s intervention.

verses.text: When he had taken him and brought him to his mother, he sat on her knees until noon, and then died.
verses.comment: The death of a cherished child parallels later gospel scenes, setting the stage for miraculous restoration.

verses.text: She went up and laid him on the bed of the man of God, shut the door, and went out.
verses.comment: Laying the child in the prophet’s room symbolically entrusts him to God’s mercy through His servant.

verses.text: Then she called to her husband and said, "Please send me one of the servants and a donkey so I can quickly go to the man of God and come back."
verses.comment: Her immediate faith and action resembles those who urgently seek help from Jesus in the Gospels.

verses.text: He asked, "Why are you going to him today? It’s not the New Moon nor the Sabbath." She said, "It is well."
verses.comment: Reference to holy days highlights the rhythm of worship, while her response "It is well" expresses deep faith.

verses.text: Then she saddled a donkey and said to her servant, "Drive, and go forward; don’t slow the pace for me unless I tell you."
verses.comment: Her urgency is reminiscent of Abraham’s zeal to respond to God’s call (Genesis 22:3), showing faith in action.

verses.text: As she came to the man of God at Mount Carmel, when the man of God saw her from afar, he said to Gehazi his servant, "Look, the Shunammite woman is coming!"
verses.comment: Mount Carmel is a site of major miracles, reinforcing the setting’s spiritual intensity.

verses.text: "Run now to meet her, and ask her, 'Are you well? Is your husband well? Is the child well?'" She answered, "It is well."
verses.comment: Her repeated affirmation of well-being despite tragedy is an expression of trust, prefiguring Christian hope in suffering.

verses.text: Now when she came to the man of God at the mountain, she caught hold of his feet. Gehazi came near to push her away, but the man of God said, "Let her alone; for her soul is in deep distress, and the LORD has hidden it from me and has not told me."
verses.comment: Her gesture of grasping Elisha’s feet recalls acts of reverence and supplication, as with Jesus, where true faith is shown through humility.

verses.text: So she said, "Did I ask my lord for a son? Did I not say, 'Do not deceive me'?"
verses.comment: Her anguish underscores the human struggle with faith and disappointment. Sincere prayer and questioning are honored by God.

verses.text: Then he said to Gehazi, "Get yourself ready, take my staff in your hand, and go. If you meet anyone, do not greet him; and if anyone greets you, do not answer; but lay my staff on the child’s face."
verses.comment: The use of the prophet’s staff presents the theme of sanctified objects, which God can use for miracles, paralleling how Christ uses physical signs.

verses.text: The mother of the child said, "As the LORD lives, and as you yourself live, I will not leave you." So he arose and followed her.
verses.comment: Her persistence and devotion are honored, similar to those who cling to God’s representatives in faith, echoing Ruth’s steadfastness.

verses.text: Gehazi went ahead of them and laid the staff on the child’s face, but there was neither voice nor response. So he returned to meet Elisha and told him, saying, "The child has not awakened."
verses.comment: Miracles are not automatic—direct intercession is required. The awakening motif hints at resurrection and new life in later revelation.

verses.text: When Elisha came into the house, there was the child, lying dead on his bed.
verses.comment: The crisis reaches its peak with death, requiring God’s direct intervention, as in Christ’s later miracles.

verses.text: He went in, shut the door behind the two of them, and prayed to the LORD.
verses.comment: Prayer in private recalls the intimacy with God required for true miracle-working power.

verses.text: He went up and lay on the child, putting his mouth on his mouth, his eyes on his eyes, and his hands on his hands; and as he stretched himself over the child, the flesh of the child became warm.
verses.comment: The prophet’s physical contact, combined with prayer, channels God’s life-giving power. Echoes Christ’s incarnational ministry.

verses.text: Then he returned and walked back and forth in the house, and again went up and stretched himself out on him; then the child sneezed seven times and opened his eyes.
verses.comment: The child’s revival with seven sneezes suggests completeness. Miracle occurs through persistent, personal intercession.

verses.text: He called Gehazi and said, "Call the Shunammite woman." When he had called her, she came to him.
verses.comment: Reintroduction of the mother emphasizes her faith and ensures she witnesses the miracle personally.

verses.text: So he said, "Pick up your son." She came in, fell at his feet, bowed to the ground, then picked up her son and went out.
verses.comment: Her bowing and gratitude prefigure acts of worship and recognition of God’s mercy at work through His chosen representatives.

verses.text: And Elisha returned to Gilgal; and there was a famine in the land. Now the sons of the prophets were sitting before him, and he said to his servant, "Set on the large pot, and boil stew for the sons of the prophets."
verses.comment: The prophet’s concern for his disciples during famine is reminiscent of Christ feeding his followers.

verses.text: One went out into the field to gather herbs, and found a wild vine, and gathered from it wild gourds, filling his cloak. When he came and sliced them into the pot of stew, though no one knew what they were.
verses.comment: Unknown food recalls the danger of not properly discerning spiritual nourishment, paralleling lessons about purity and discernment.

verses.text: Then they served it to the men to eat. But as they ate the stew, they cried out and said, "Man of God, there is death in the pot!" And they could not eat.
verses.comment: Death in the pot symbolizes the seriousness of discernment in spiritual matters, and the need for purification.

verses.text: But he said, "Then bring some flour." And he put it into the pot, and said, "Serve it to the people, so that they may eat." And there was nothing harmful in the pot.
verses.comment: The addition of flour purifies the stew, a figure of transformation and sanctification. Prefigures how ordinary things can become instruments of grace.

verses.text: Then a man came from Baal Shalishah and brought the man of God bread of the firstfruits, twenty loaves of barley bread, and some new grain in his sack. And he said, "Give it to the people so they may eat."
verses.comment: Bread of firstfruits points to offering and blessing, paralleling the multiplication of bread in Christ’s ministry (Mark 6:35-44).

verses.text: But his servant said, "What? Should I set this before a hundred men?" He said again, "Give it to the people, so that they may eat; for thus says the LORD: 'They shall eat and have some left over.'"
verses.comment: Miraculous feeding with leftovers closely foreshadows Christ’s feeding miracles, underscoring divine abundance.

verses.text: So he set it before them; and they ate and had some left over, according to the word of the LORD.
verses.comment: God’s word brings about miraculous abundance, prefiguring the Eucharistic imagery and Christ’s ministry of satisfying all who come in faith.
